I have a '46 chevy pickup I purchased a sa project truck (had to cut a tree out of the engine compartment to get it). It has been more or less sittign while I decide what I want to do with it. Current plans include a 400hp smallblock, suspension from a navigator (unless I can find a donor suburban with the 4 wheel steering), all modern conveniences. 
 
 The only question left is whether to chop the top or not. I am not talkig enything too severe, a couple inches maybe. 
 
 Here is a page with pictures of a '46 stock:
 
 http://www.dealsonwheels.com/search/dealerbig.cfm?Autos__ID=000778-200507-000010
 
 Here is one with a 2" chop:
 
 http://www.hotrods.ca/Features/Photos/StanZink.jpg
 
 Here is one that is beat to death witha rediculously high price tag:
 
 http://www.oldchevytruck.com/trucks8/zf.htm
 
 Sheesh. I paid $500 for mine, and it has a better looking body than that.
 
 Anyway, what do you folks think? Chop it or not? I am going to try to stick close to stock height (though I will gain about an inch with the navigator suspension). There is plenty of headroom, you can chop them 5" before things start to seem at all cramped.

 I painted one project, a frame-off 60 MB SL 190, never again. It was in 1979, in a garage with inadequate ventilation, white lacquer and a very unpleasant memory. The job came out fine, but I no longer have the desire to prep for paint. A pro paint job here, perfect and they have to bless the bodywork or will refuse to do it, is $5k up, bare body to them. That's masked, blocked, sanded, primer, single base color and clear coat.
 
 I agree most aftermarket repros are of poor quality, but one can build many old Chevys or Fords from scratch including frame and body. I've gone through the search for NOS parts for a few projects and it's a big, big chore. eBay made it much easier, but, since old iron has had high interest for many years, prices for NOS/original/excellent take my breath away. A primary reason is their investment value. A 100-point FI '57 Chevy convertible with all the goodies costs about the same as a decent starter home. I'm not in that league, but I do lust for original Dusenbergs and 427 Cobras.

Interestingly enough, of the 2 '46 pickups I have done (that is the only model I have ever done more than one of), the one I restored completely to original sold for almost twice what the updated one did. As for me, if I am building something I am going to drive, I prefer to have more than 90 HP (especially on a 5000 lb truck), and I like my air conditioner, CD player, digital gauges that actually work, independant suspension, and the ability to go just slightly faster than the 45 mph that the truck was originally intended to travel.
